page.title: 18WILDLIFE AROUND ADELAIDE (i)
page.content: The most important habitat for wildlife is the Beet Settling Ponds dug in the 1930's as pits in which to wash the sugar beet.They provide water for wildfowl,mud banks for waders and herbage for nesting birds.Resident birds which also nest include mistle, blackbird and song thrush,collared dove,black_headed gull,coot,moorhen, mallard,tufted duck,pheasant,mute swan and partridge.Summer migrants are reed and sedge warblers,swifts,swallows, sand and house martins,shelduck,little grebe,cuckoo and turtle dove.Winter visitors are redwing,fieldfare,bearded tit,teal,shovelor,pochard,wigeon and cormorant.Spring and Autumn passage migrants include black_tailed godwit, curlew sandpiper,greenshank,black, common and sandwich terns,little gull, hen and marsh harrier.
